title: Quiz 5: Treatments & Pharmacology
topicName: Unit 1: Mental Health and Psychiatric Nursing
description: Comprehensive review of psychiatric medications, ECT, and psychotherapy.

questions.question: Which drug is a high-potency antipsychotic used for acute psychosis?
questions.explanation: Haloperidol is a high-potency antipsychotic. Chlorpromazine is low-potency; Diazepam is an anxiolytic.
questions.hint: Starts with 'H' and is often given IM.

questions.question: Match the side effect to the drug class:
questions.explanation: EPS -> Antipsychotics; Tyramine reaction -> MAOIs; Addiction -> Anxiolytics.
questions.hint: Connect specific risks to drug types.

questions.question: Before Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT), ___BLANK___ is given to dry secretions, and the patient must be starved for ___BLANK___ hours.
questions.explanation: Atropine 0.6mg dries secretions; 6 hours NPO prevents aspiration.
questions.hint: A common pre-op drug and standard fasting time.

questions.question: Which of the following are Extra Pyramidal Symptoms (EPS)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Dystonia, Oculogyric crisis, Akathisia, and Torticollis are EPS. Hypertension is not.

questions.question: What is the recommended antidote for a hypertensive crisis caused by MAOIs?
questions.explanation: Regitine (Phentolamine) is used to lower blood pressure in MAOI crisis.

questions.question: Antiparkinsonian drugs like Benztropine are given to counteract the side effects of major tranquilisers.
questions.explanation: They treat EPS caused by antipsychotics.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT) preparation:
Which type of psychotherapy relies on 'suggestibility' and includes hypnosis?
Which foods must be avoided by patients taking Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors (MAOIs)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Foods containing Tyramine (aged cheese, alcohol, liver, chocolate) must be avoided.

questions.question: What is the term for the 'wormlike movement of the tongue' side effect associated with long-term antipsychotic use?
questions.explanation: Tardive Dyskinesia involves involuntary movements like tongue rolling.
